verses.text: These are the sons of Israel: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
verses.comment: This begins the genealogy of the tribes of Israel. The line of Judah is highlighted particularly, as Christ will come from this tribe. See Matt. 1:2-3.

verses.text: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
verses.comment: All twelve sons of Israel (Jacob) are listed. They become the patriarchs of the tribes. Their unity is foundational for the people of God.

verses.text: The sons of Judah: Er, Onan, and Shelah. These three were born to him by Bath-shua, the Canaanite woman. Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, so He put him to death.
verses.comment: The special focus on Judah's line foreshadows the Davidic and Messianic line. God's direct judgment demonstrates His sovereignty. Compare Rom. 9:14-18 regarding God's choices.

verses.text: Tamar, his daughter-in-law, bore him Perez and Zerah. Judah had five sons in all.
verses.comment: Tamar's place in the genealogy shows God's plan often uses unexpected people. The line of the Messiah passes through Perez (Luke 3:33).

verses.text: The sons of Perez: Hezron and Hamul.
verses.comment: Hezron's line is traced directly to David and thus to Christ, signifying the importance of genealogical records for establishing true priesthood and kingship.

verses.text: The sons of Zerah: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara—five in all.
verses.comment: Some of these names appear elsewhere as wise men in Israel, showing the prominence of Zerah's descendants.

verses.text: The son of Carmi was Achar, the troubler of Israel, who broke faith regarding the devoted thing.
verses.comment: Achar (Achan) brought trouble through disobedience. Faithfulness and obedience to God's commands are foundational.

verses.text: The son of Ethan was Azariah.
verses.comment: Every name in the genealogy carries meaning for the overall redemptive story of God’s people.

verses.text: The sons born to Hezron were: Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.
verses.comment: Hezron’s line is crucial, particularly Ram, ancestor of David and symbolizing the succession of true spiritual authority.

verses.text: Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, leader of the descendants of Judah.
verses.comment: Nahshon plays an important role in the Exodus, reflecting the importance of faithful leadership in God’s plan (Rom. 15:12).

verses.text: Nahshon fathered Salma, and Salma fathered Boaz.
verses.comment: Boaz, a redeemer, is an image of Christ, our ultimate Redeemer.

verses.text: Boaz fathered Obed, and Obed fathered Jesse.
verses.comment: Jesse, the father of David, marks the main Messianic line. The emphasis on genealogy provides the foundation for identifying the true Messiah.

verses.text: Jesse fathered Eliab, his firstborn, Abinadab the second, Shimea the third,
verses.comment: David was the youngest, emphasizing God’s choice does not follow human expectations.

verses.text: Nethanel the fourth, Raddai the fifth,
verses.comment: Every son of Jesse is named, highlighting the special place of David’s family.

verses.text: Ozem the sixth, David the seventh.
verses.comment: David, the youngest, chosen by God. Points to the mystery of divine election in the establishment of spiritual authority (Matt. 22:14).

verses.text: Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. The sons of Zeruiah: Abishai, Joab, and Asahel—three.
verses.comment: Zeruiah’s sons were prominent generals under David, showing God’s providence in raising up leaders for His people.

verses.text: Abigail bore Amasa, and the father of Amasa was Jether the Ishmaelite.
verses.comment: Amasa became a military leader; familial lines provide unity and order for God’s people.

verses.text: Caleb the son of Hezron had children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth; her sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
verses.comment: Caleb’s line will carry forward into priestly and kingly heritage.

verses.text: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.
verses.comment: Hur’s descendants become important builders and artisans in Israel’s history.

verses.text: Hur fathered Uri, and Uri fathered Bezalel.
verses.comment: Bezalel is the craftsman for the Tabernacle, a type of Christ building the true spiritual Temple (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: Afterward, Hezron went in to the daughter of Machir, the father of Gilead—he married her when he was sixty years old—and she bore him Segub.
verses.comment: Hezron’s later marriage yields Segub, showing God’s blessing in all stages of life.

verses.text: Segub fathered Jair, who had twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead.
verses.comment: Jair’s dominion foreshadows faithful stewardship; see Christ’s parables regarding stewardship (Luke 19:11-27).

verses.text: But Geshur and Aram took from them the towns of Jair, Kenath and its villages, sixty towns. All these were descendants of Machir, the father of Gilead.
verses.comment: The political changes remind us of the fragility of earthly inheritance and the importance of an unbroken spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: After the death of Hezron in Caleb-Ephrathah, Abijah, Hezron’s wife, bore Ashhur, the father of Tekoa.
verses.comment: Tekoa becomes home to prophets, including Amos. Genealogy preserves prophecy’s context.

verses.text: The sons of Jerahmeel, the firstborn of Hezron: Ram the firstborn, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
verses.comment: Jerahmeel’s descendants form an administrative class, supporting the worship and order of Israel.

verses.text: Jerahmeel had another wife, named Atarah, who was the mother of Onam.
verses.comment: Polygamy appears in the Old Testament stories, but God’s plan ultimately points toward the unity of faith and family.

verses.text: The sons of Ram, the firstborn of Jerahmeel: Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
verses.comment: Each generation preserves the line of promise.

verses.text: The sons of Onam: Shammai and Jada. The sons of Shammai: Nadab and Abishur.
verses.comment: These names are preserved to maintain the history and continuity of the chosen people.

verses.text: The name of Abishur’s wife was Abihail, and she bore him Ahban and Molid.
verses.comment: Women are mentioned alongside their children, indicating their important role in continuing the sacred lineage.

verses.text: The sons of Nadab: Seled and Appaim. Seled died without children.
verses.comment: A line ending without children has implications for inheritance and legacy, themes fulfilled in Christ’s eternal kingship.

verses.text: The son of Appaim: Ishi. The son of Ishi: Sheshan. The son of Sheshan: Ahlai.
verses.comment: Generations continue despite setbacks, illustrating God's faithfulness.

verses.text: The sons of Jada, the brother of Shammai: Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without children.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s line will continue, again showing the survival of the promise.

verses.text: The sons of Jonathan: Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.
verses.comment: Lineage details matter because they establish the credibility of succession and authority.

verses.text: Now Sheshan had no sons, only daughters. Sheshan had an Egyptian servant named Jarha.
verses.comment: Daughters’ importance is recognized. The joining of Jarha points to the expanding family of God.

verses.text: Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his servant Jarha, and she bore him Attai.
verses.comment: Marriage outside Israel, though rare, is included, showing the wideness of God’s providential plan.

verses.text: Attai fathered Nathan, and Nathan fathered Zabad.
verses.comment: Nathan’s name is later significant in royal prophecy (2 Sam. 7:2-16).

verses.text: Zabad fathered Ephlal, and Ephlal fathered Obed.
verses.comment: Obed’s name recalls the grandfather of David, keeping David’s ancestry alive in memory.

verses.text: Obed fathered Jehu, and Jehu fathered Azariah.
verses.comment: Each descendant carries a remnant of sacred history, each with an irreplaceable role.

verses.text: Azariah fathered Helez, and Helez fathered Eleasah.
verses.comment: Preservation and succession are emphasized in Old Testament faithfulness.

verses.text: Eleasah fathered Sismai, and Sismai fathered Shallum.
verses.comment: Consistency and faithfulness in generations prepare the ground for continuity of God’s worship.

verses.text: Shallum fathered Jekamiah, and Jekamiah fathered Elishama.
verses.comment: Elishama’s name means 'God hears,' a reminder of God's covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: The sons of Caleb, the brother of Jerahmeel: Mesha his firstborn, who was the father of Ziph; and the sons of Mareshah the father of Hebron.
verses.comment: Caleb and his descendants become important landholders and leaders during Israel’s settlement.

verses.text: The sons of Hebron: Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
verses.comment: Hebron’s offspring are foundational contributors to the occupied Promised Land.

verses.text: Shema fathered Raham, the father of Jorkeam; and Rekem fathered Shammai.
verses.comment: Each town originated with a family and reflects the kinship-based order of Old Testament Israel.

verses.text: The son of Shammai was Maon; and Maon was the father of Beth-zur.
verses.comment: Settlement centers are often named after their founders, showing continuity of community and worship.

verses.text: Ephah, Caleb’s concubine, bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran fathered Gazez.
verses.comment: Even children of concubines are listed, signifying all who participate in Israel's blessings.

verses.text: The sons of Jahdai: Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
verses.comment: Every family member is given importance, suggesting the unity of Israel’s wider community.

verses.text: Maacah, Caleb’s concubine, bore Sheber and Tirhanah.
verses.comment: Reminds us of God’s providence even through complex family structures.

verses.text: She also bore Shaaph the father of Madmannah, Sheva the father of Machbenah and the father of Gibea; and the daughter of Caleb was Achsah.
verses.comment: Achsah, named among men, receives an inheritance, prefiguring the spiritual inheritance through Christ for all the faithful.

verses.text: These were the descendants of Caleb: the sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah: Shobal the father of Kiriath-jearim,
verses.comment: Kiriath-jearim becomes a center for the ark, symbolizing the presence of God among His people.

verses.text: Salma the father of Bethlehem, Hareph the father of Beth-gader.
verses.comment: Bethlehem is the city of David and the birthplace of Jesus, fulfilling Messianic prophecy (Micah 5:2).

verses.text: Shobal the father of Kiriath-jearim had descendants: Haroeh, and half of the Menuhoth.
verses.comment: Lines trace not just people but the founding of worship centers in Israel.

verses.text: The families of Kiriath-jearim: the Ithrites, Puthites, Shumathites, and Mishraites. From these came the Zorathites and Eshtaolites.
verses.comment: These towns become centers of spiritual revival, such as in the story of Samson.

verses.text: The sons of Salma: Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, half the Manahathites, the Zorites,
verses.comment: Bethlehem is vital in redemptive history, home of David and Jesus (Luke 2:4-7).

verses.text: And the families of scribes who lived at Jabez: the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. These are the Kenites who came from Hammath, the father of the house of Rechab.
verses.comment: The scribes play a crucial role in preserving Scripture and instruction, prefiguring the preserving and teaching role of the visible Church.
